results.description:
Currently MB prepares planet examples one at a time and in a sequence.

When the user is connected to a slow internet connection, it can often take a long time for a desired project to load.

I suspect that there is a way to load projects faster. Perhaps start with loading all the names of projects first in order to make them searchable immediately--then render the graphics for thumbnails etc.

Also, does MB keep any of this in the browser cache? It may make loading faster if the browser cache were used between sessions and then just updated when needed during subsequent sessions.

> We can try caching between sessions. To download names first would require changes on the server side.
results.name: Music Blocks #905: Explore quicker ways to have access to planet examples

results.description:
Create an account on github.com and then follow the instructions in the Hello World tutorial (https://guides.github.com/activities/hello-world), where you will learn how to:

1. Create and use a repository;
2. Start and manage a new branch;
3. Make changes to a file and push them to GitHub as commits; and
4. Open and merge a pull request.

Once you have completed the tutorial, please:

1. Create a new branch of your repository called "sugarlabs" (Please take note of the branch name you should be using to complete this task.);
2. Edit the README.md file to include the phrase., "Hello Sugar Labs" along with some personal message that includes your name.
3. Commit the change;
4. Make a pull request for the change.
5. Merge that branch back to your master branch.
6. When you are done, please upload (or paste as a comment) the URL to your repository to complete this task.

Note that this is essentially the same workflow you will use for most of the coding tasks. Rather than creating a new repository, you will often be making a clone of an existing repository to which you will make your changes. Your pull requests will be to the original repository. Sugar Labs community members will do the final merge **, but your task will be complete once a mentor has signed off on your pull request.

** however, in this task, you should do the merge yourself.
results.name: Make a pull request

results.description:
```create-react-app``` is a powerful command-line tool that simplifies the creation of React/TypeScript projects.
# Task Description
You are to scaffold a React/TypeScript project using the command ```create-react-app```

# Getting Started
You need to have Node.js installed on your machine. If you don't have it. Head to the Node.js download [page](https://nodejs.org) and grab the version you need.

# Helpful Links and Articles
* [How to set up a React/TypeScript project using create-react-app](https://codeburst.io/https-medium-com-chidumennamdi-how-to-setup-a-react-js-typescript-project-using-create-react-app-4ca1fcc93e4b) by **Chidume Nnamdi** in **Codeburst.io**
* [Learning React with create-react-app](https://medium.com/@diamondgfx/learning-react-with-create-react-app-part-1-a12e1833fdc) by **Brandon Richey** in **Medium.com**
* [create-react-app Github repo](https://github.com/facebookincubator/create-react-app) - A **Github** repo.
* [Getting started with React.js and TypeScript](https://javascriptplayground.com/blog/2017/04/react-typescript/)
* [Microsoft TypeScript React Started Github repo](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript-React-Starter)

The above links will get you get started on how to set up a React/TypeScript project.

# Task Submission.
Following through the above tutorials, you will create a Github repo of the React/TypeScript project you built. When done upload the Github link for evaluation: 

# Contact
Got a question, a problem or just want to talk? Please get in touch with us!
results.name: Set up a React/TypeScript project using the create-react-app utility

results.description:
Google Cloud Function is a platform whereby you can execute your server-side code without the need of setting up the server environment.
# Task Description
You are to create a Google Cloud Function that sends "Hello World" back to the user. This should be able to give a response back to any anyone that calls the Cloud Function using a cURL, an HTTP request or a URL request from a browser.

# Getting Started
You need to install Node.js on your machine. If you don't already have the Node.js environment, download the executable from their website [Node.js](https://nodejs.org).

# Example
 * (https://us-central1-myreddit-clone.cloudfunctions.net/getContactList)
The above link is a Google Cloud Function I set up for my tutorial am about to release on Medium. Navigating to the URL will run the Cloud Function associated with it. You will see on the screen of your browser the lists of contacts it fetched from the Cloud Store. 
Take a cue from that and create your own Cloud Function that will display "Hello World" on the user's browser.

# Helpful Links and Articles
* [Google Cloud Platform](https://cloud.google.com/functions/)
* [Getting Started: Write and Deploy your First Functions](https://firebase.google.com/docs/functions/get-started) - Firebase
* [Getting Started with Google Cloud Functions](https://www.programmableweb.com/news/getting-started-google-cloud-functions/how-to/2017/06/05)

# Task Submission
Please, send us the link to the Github repo for evaluation:

# Contact
Please, Feel free to contact any of the mentors or drop us a line if any need to.

# What you will learn
You will get to know how Serverless platforms makes a developer work easier and stress-free.
results.name: Set up a Google Cloud Function that returns "Hello World" to the browser.

results.description:
# Task Description
An npm module or Node.js module is a simple or complex functionality organized in single or multiple JavaScript files that can be reused throughout a Node.js application.
You are actually going to write a JavaScript module that will help Node.js developers anywhere in the world.

So what you are required to do is write and publish a simple npm module that will print "Hello World" in the console.

# Node.js Installation
First, download the Node.js, which is installable from [Node.js Website](https://nodejs.org) the download and install the executable suitable for your machine OS.

**Help**: You can read the following articles to help you understand what you need to do:
* [How to create and write an npm module using TypeScript]( https://codeburst.io/https-chidume-nnamdi-com-npm-module-in-typescript-12b3b22f0724) by **Chidume Nnamdi** in **Codeburst**.
* [How to build an publish an npm package](https://scotch.io/bar-talk/how-to-build-and-publish-a-npm-package) by **Akinjide Bankole** in **Scotch.io**
* [How to create and publish your first Node.js module](https://codeburst.io/how-to-create-and-publish-your-first-node-js-module-444e7585b738)

# Task Submission.
Following through the above tutorials, you will create a Github repo of the npm module you built. When done upload the Github link for evaluation: 

What are you waiting for? Make your own Node.js today!

# Contact
Got a question, a problem or just want to talk? Please get in touch with us!

Of course, when you are done you will forever be in [npmjs](npmjs.com) as a contributor to Open Source.
results.name: Write a npm Node.js module that prints "Hello World"

results.description: We are migrating to a new activity server (ASLO3) and in the process are trying to do some housekeeping. We have a spreadsheet with a list of acitivites that are missing their license field. The task here is to figure out the proper license and to add a LICENSE file to the repo via a github pull request. (Note that some repos use COPYING instead of LICENSE, which is OK.) The license is usually evident in the .py files. (Also, please ensure that there are both a repository field and a license field in the activity.info file and that the repository field accurately points to the correct repo.) Do ten activities to complete the task.
results.name: Treasure hunt: find a repo/find a license

results.description: As described in the GitHub issue linked to below, there is a problem with relative paths in the minified version of airspace.css. The problem occurs because the relative paths are defined from the css directory, but the minified version of the file is put in a different directory. Three solutions are described in the issue, but the task is to implement solution #1: move the minified file (renamed) to the css directory. This will require you to also update the path in _layouts/base.html, where the minified file is imported. Once you are done, the are four different places where imports would have failed, most notably the background image for the div near the top of the main page. Please test to ensure all four relative paths are being properly imported.
results.name: www.sugarlabs.org Bad path for background image in minified css

This should all be possible with current tools, but has yet to be done.

One might start with something simple like "Hot Cross Buns".

Many solutions, I guess, but could try the following:

pitch number block as input to mouse vertical motion (coordinates or forward/back)

results.description:
harmonics are the overtones that are included in a particular pitch.

They are a defining feature of a sound.

It would be nice to have a feature that allows the user to access just one of the overtones of a note.

0 would be just the fundamental
1 would be first overtone
2 would be second overtone
etc.

(I lack the imagination to know what negative numbers would do. They do not really exist in the real world--more of a theoretical construct as far as I can tell.)

It would be a clamp that goes over a pitch.

All the other sounds for the enclosed pitch would be discarded and only the specified overtone (or overtones in the case of multiple clamps) would be performed.

See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overtones for some basic info on overtones.

Side note: I thought that tone.js had a feature to control overtones specifically, but I cannot find it now. It is worth looking into before starting this issue.
results.name: Music Blocks #912: Harmonics Block

results.description:
When we take out "timbre" widget from the widget palette, initially, it has a "custom" input. We need to design and implement the ability to store and retrieve multiple custom timbres for the "timbre" widget, which means supporting the addition of multiple "timbres" in the widget palette with customized inputs. For example, if a custom timbre is taken out from the palette, it can have a combination of "envelope" and "oscillator" as a beginning point , whereas another custom timbre can have "envelope" and "effects".
The inputs of the custom timbre should be a frequently used musical combination.

There is a voicename block that is used to select the timbre. It is a selector. What we want to do is add a new entry to the array used by the selector whenever a custom timbre is saved.

The selector is build from the VOICENAMES array in musicutils.js. So the task would be to add the new voicename to the end of that array whenever saving from the timbre widget (timbre.js). Be sure to not add duplicate entries.

In a separate task, we can save/restore custom timbres between sessions.
results.name: Music Blocks: Custom timbres for timbre widget

results.description:
Sugarizer presence allow real time communication between users of an activity. See for example on the Paint activity: launch Paint activity, click on network toolbar then on the multidot icon, launch Sugarizer from another browser, go to the neighborhood view and join the paint activity.
The task is to write a tutorial to explain how to easily integrate presence API into a new activity. The tutorial will start from the "Create your own activity" tutorial https://github.com/llaske/Sugarizer/tree/dev#create-your-own-activity then add features to integrate presence.
Here steps of this new tutorial:
- Add a presence button to the toolbar
- Create the presence palette
- Get the presence object using : activity.getPresenceObject() 
- Call presence.createSharedActivity to create a new share
- Watch events onDataReceived (someone sendMessage on the share), onSharedActivityUserChanged (an user enter/leave the share) and onConnectionClosed
- Send data to the share using sendMessage
- Check window.top.sugar.environment.sharedId variable to see if the activity has been launched from the neighborhood view with a "Join".
You could use source code that do the same thing here https://github.com/llaske/sugarizer/blob/dev/activities/SharedNotes.activity/js/activity.js#L437
The new activity could be a very simple one, for example: display a button on the activity and when a connected user click on it, the background/foreground of the window change for all users connected using colors of user that clicked.
results.name: Write a tutorial on Sugarizer Presence

results.description:

A current video tutorial explaining how to develop a Sugarizer activity from scratch exist on https://github.com/llaske/sugarizer/blob/dev/README.md#create-your-own-activity. 
This video should be adapted to integrate porting of Blockrain. It should also adapted to:
- Consider that a Sugarizer Server environment is already running on the computer (https://github.com/llaske/sugarizer-server/blob/master/README.md)
- Do not package Sugarizer as a Chrome Desktop Application, just launch Sugarizer from Chrome or Firefox
The tutorial should insist to show that it's very important to call "activity.setup()" at start of the activity to ensure a good Sugarizer integration (activity icon will use the current user color, stop button will redirect to home, ...).
results.name: Porting webapp to Sugarizer activity video tutorial

results.description:
Currently, when visiting the planet part of the UI there is an image of a mouse for all of the Music Blocks code that is on the planet server.



This mouse image has had a good run (it served its purpose for some time), but I think that we can do better. The mouse image does not do a good job to clue someone into what they might hear, and there are ways we can better represent the expected sound visually.



I am seeking some better ideas. Some starting places are:



* What about just showing an image of some of the code as the thumbnail?

* Is there a way to show some of the output music notation? (I do not imagine this to be possible as our notation output is lilypond, but why not mention it.)

* Perhaps some graphical notation (i.e. graphical in the same way our pitch-time matrix is graphical)



Happy to hear other ideas.
results.name: MusicBlocks Issue: #854: Seeking proposals for better image ideas for planet.

results.description:
# Task Description
You are to set up an Angular project using the angular/cli command-line utility. All that this task requires you to do is install the angular/cli module via npm and initialize a new project using the commands it offers. 

# Getting Started
You need a [Node.js](https://nodejs.org) environment to get started. Head over to Node.js website to download the installable file if you don't have it.

# Help Links and Articles
* [Building an Angular 4 Component Library with the Angular CLI and ng-packagr](https://medium.com/@ngl817/building-an-angular-4-component-library-with-the-angular-cli-and-ng-packagr-53b2ade0701e) by **Nicholas LeBlanc** in **Medium.com**
* [Use the angular-cli for faster Angular 2 projects](https://scotch.io/tutorials/use-the-angular-cli-for-faster-angular-2-projects) by **Chris Sevilleja** in **Scotch.io**
* [Ultimate Angular-CLI reference](https://www.sitepoint.com/ultimate-angular-cli-reference/)
* [Building an angular 4 component library with angular-cli and ng-packagr](https://medium.com/@ngl817/building-an-angular-4-component-library-with-the-angular-cli-and-ng-packagr-53b2ade0701e) - in **Medium.com**

# Task Submission.
Following through the above tutorials, you will create a Github repo of the Angular project you built. When done upload the Github link for evaluation: 

Start using Angular today!

# Contact US
Got a question, a problem or just want to talk? Please get in touch with us!
results.name: Scaffold an Angular project using the angular/cli utility

results.description:
Sugarizer Deployment Tool is a tool to configure multiple Android devices at once.

**In order to do this task you will need Android devices or you'll have to install Android emulators**

In this task you will learn how to use the Sugarizer Deployment Tool to create "recipes" and how to apply them on devices.

Having this knowledge you will write a Markdown document for the other users. **The majority of users won't be technical.**
You may have to take several screenshots and pictures.

Steps :

-Get and launch the latest release of the app 
https://github.com/llaske/sugarizer-deployment-tool-desktop/releases/tag/v1.0

-Download some apks to do some test
You can use this apk from https://f-droid.org/packages/org.olpc_france.sugarizer/  (direct link : https://f-droid.org/repo/org.olpc_france.sugarizer_9000.apk)

-Try to connect your Android device to your computer. (Please enable ADB https://developer.android.com/studio/command-line/adb.html#Enabling).
**Or** start an Android emulator

-Try to drag and drop your apk on the bottom left of the first screen and see if it worked.

-Go to the second tab and try to create a "recipe" and pick up any instructions you want.
-Go back on the first tab and launch your recipe.

You may now try to write your own detailled tutorial to allow anyone to use the app !
results.name: Write the Sugarizer Deployment Tool user documentation

results.description:
Independently reproduce Sugar Live Build and improve documentation.

When we released Sugar 0.112 a Debian Live Build was made for demonstrating, using, and developing for Sugar.  Sugar Live Build is a complete bootable image containing Sugar and demonstration activities.


We need;

1.  a README.md in the sugar-live-build repository to explain briefly (a) that repository contains configuration files for Debian Live Build, and (b) how to reproduce the build,

2.  community edited Wiki pages for Sugar Live Build (page name Live_Build), with inline or subpage answers to frequently asked questions such as how to install, how to test, and how to reproduce,

3.  community agreement and implementation of a transition to using download.sugarlabs.org for hosting live builds instead of people.sugarlabs.org,

4.  documentation in a Wiki subpage of how to add additional Sugar activities and reproduce a build for a classroom,

5.  community agreement to remove some quite old images on download.sugarlabs.org, which are out of date, unmaintained, consume disk space, and have software security vulnerabilities.


Prerequisites;

a.  subscription to sugar-devel@ and systems@ mailing lists,

b.  a Debian system, a schroot on an Ubuntu system, or a Debian virtual machine,

c.  internet access to download or upload ISO files of about 1GB each,

d.  a Sugar Labs shell account https://wiki.sugarlabs.org/go/Service/shell
results.name: Sugar Live Build documentation

results.description:
A monochord is a single string instrument.

Read more at: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monochord and https://ulibarri.website/owncloud/index.php/s/JHcQzs4XLAYWlVo

and see this image:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monochord

This task's goal:
* Use as much of the screen as possible
* Use art (mouse palette) to show the user where the divisions are on the screen.
* Use sensors so that someone running the code would hear accurate audio output according to the physics of a monochord (see the article for the math)
* You only need to recreate half of the string.

Extra Credit:
* EASY: Make the monochord "tunable" using box feature to specify a variable
* MEDIUM: allow for any number of divisions within the half of the string by using another variable.
* HARD: create logic for the code, such that divisions outside the first half are possible (multiple octaves) and can be specified by the user.
results.name: Create an interactive monochord with Music Blocks

results.description:
Please read the following documents: https://ulibarri.website/owncloud/index.php/s/O7TARbmTINif5gd

Strahles Guitar is a method for using geometry to create the fretboard of a guitar with frets positioned very close to equal temperament.

The first part of the task is to use the art features (mouse palette) from Music Blocks to create the geometry necessary to position the frets.

Once you have found the correct position for the frets, create a way for those frets to be performed. It could be as simple as having the mouse move across the fretboard performing each note. Or you could challenge yourself my making the guitar interactive in some way.

You need only create the first octave (the first half of the fretboard) as in the linked document.
results.name: Strahles Guitar -- use geometry to make the fretboard of a guitar!

results.description:
Pythagorean tuning has the following properties:

1. The numerator and denominator of each ration are always a power of 2 or 3.
2. All perfect fifths are in the ratio 3:2.
3. All five whole steps in the major scale are in the ratio W = 9:8.
4. Both half steps in the major scale are in the ratio H = 256:243.
5. Two half steps do not equal one whole step, that is, H^2 does not equal W!

This task focuses on the second property.

This second property is important because it means that the starting pitch never reaches its octave! Please see the linked documents for an image of how this causes a "spiral of fifths". https://ulibarri.website/owncloud/index.php/s/UVb0JnFBf510L9U

The goal is to use art elements (from the mouse palette) to draw either a circle or a spiral (either a circle or a spiral are okay). If you choose a circle, then make sure the output does not get cluttered (by removing points as you go around, for example).

Like in the linked chart, you will want to print the note names of the result.

As for the audio output, you will want to use mathematical operations on a note (possibly a hertz block) so that the resulting pitches are mathematically accurate.

The audio and visual output should be connected such that the note name being printed is the note being sounded.
results.name: Code a Pythagorean "spiral of fifths"

When opening any page on developer.sugarlabs.org, the keyboard navigation feature does not work.  This does not comply with accessibility guidelines.



Please fix the generated HTML or CSS so that keyboard scrolling is available after page load.



Occurs on Browse-200, Chromium-53, Firefox-52, and most other browsers.



Does not affect mouse-wheel or touchscreen scrolling.



Workaround is to click in the body of the page first.  Keys are page down, page up, arrow down, arrow up, home, end, and space bar.



Reproducer:

* using a desktop or laptop computer, open http://developer.sugarlabs.org/

* click on ''Contribute code'' and wait for page to load,

* press page down key on keyboard.



Expected result:

* the content shall scroll,



Observed result:

* the key is ignored.
results.name: sugar-docs Issue: #121: Accessibility; keyboard navigation does not work

results.description:
Right now Music Blocks is tempered [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Musical_temperament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Musical_temperament) to equal temperament [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equal_temperament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equal_temperament)

However, that is not the only type of temperament possible.

Overall, it varies:

1. Just Intonation, where one tunes to the harmonic series.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Just_intonation

It sounds super-nice, but is impractical (impossible, perhaps) for music that changes keys at all.

2. Meantone, where you choose a key to center around and make compromises for intonation in the other keys. Modulations to related keys will sound more in-tune; modulations to distant keys will sound more out-of-tune.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meantone_temperament

There are various types of meantone temperament, but the basic premises is a kind of compromise between Just intonation "purity" and practicality.

3. Equal Temperament (ET)

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equal_temperament

ET divides the octave into twelve equal divisions.

It makes modulations very practical since there is no difference in interval size among the keys (i.e. a major third in Amaj is the same distance proportionally as a major third in Cmajor, and without retuning the instrument)...

See the issue in GitHub for task details...
results.name: MusicBlocks Issue: #485: Tackling Temperament

results.description:
In equal temperament tuning, C# == Db, etc. But in many other tuning systems, this assumption is not true. In preparation for supporting non-equal temperament tuning systems, it would be useful to have an internal mapping between the 21 possible note descriptions and the actual notes in the tuning system. This would supplant some of the assumptions, such as EQUIVALENTNOTES defined in musicutils.js

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_meantone_intervals may be useful.
results.name: MusicBlocks Issue: #876: preparation for non-equal temperament tuning

results.description:
The doubly block is specific to augmented and diminished interval calculations. If an interval is cascaded through a doubly block, it is either increased or decreased by one semitone. When a perfect, major or minor interval are cascaded through the block, there is no change. When a non-interval block is cascaded through, the value is simply doubled (x2).

The problem is that doubly doubly does not work. The second doubly doubles the value of the interval rather than further incrementing it.
results.name: MusicBlocks Issue #908: doubly doubly is not calculated properly

results.description:
Somewhat related to https://github.com/walterbender/musicblocks/issues/726 however this investigation would be into how we might change the way MB handles performance so that it can keep its groove going even when overhead is high.

For example, (one thing that gives me the idea is) when streaming video online, some streaming software will change the quality of the video depending on the users bandwidth--defaulting to less intensive streaming quality when the connection is slow. Our issue is not the same as this, but I think this general idea is worth pursuing.

Is there a way to monitor master clock so that MB knows when it is overloaded (e.g. when the difference between intended time and performed time becomes greater than a certain time)? Would this be helpful?
Are there ways to fall back to less process demanding audio when the program becomes overloaded?
Is there a way to skip some of the rendering of the art in order to maintain timing?
results.name: MusicBlocks #907: Other approaches to handling performance limitations

results.description:
A register block would be helpful.

The design would be simple. It would basically transpose subsequent notes by octaves up or down.

It would not be a clamp. Just a plain block with one argument for a number.

register = 2 -- adds two to octave of subsequent notes
register = 1 -- adds one to octave of subsequent notes
register = 0 -- no change to octave of subsequent notes
register = -1 -- subtracts one to octave of subsequent notes
register = -2 -- subtracts two to octave of subsequent notes

etc.

This would be helpful for two main reasons:

relative nature of octave in our movable systems makes such a feature useful
the default octave is 4. For lazy coders--myself included; someone may just code everything relative to octave 4 (in fixed or movable do) and then want to move everything by register using this block. And the "transpose block" in such an instance seems like an overstatement of what the user is really trying to do in such an instance.
I somewhat suspect that this block would solve one part of what can make manipulating octave awkward.
results.name: Music Blocks #906: Register Block

results.description:
I think that it would be best to add a numeric argument for dot so that the user can easily "double" and "triple" and "quadruple" dot without having to add multiple dot blocks.

The dot block macros would have the value of 1 by default (one dot).

0 would toggle dot off.

===

Dot can be described as:

for a note value x and a dot value of y

dotted_note = x + (x/2^y)

===

Negative values

At first, -1 sounded illogical to me -- however, it seems to make a kind of "inverse dot", which is kind of interesting.
results.name: Music Blocks #897: Add arg to dot

Reproducer: set the icon used by Browse download to 90%, then 99%.



Observed result: no difference in icon fill.



Expected result: difference in icon fill.



Does not occur with an icon where the fill area extends to the full height of the icon.



Cause is that the entire icon height is used for calculation, instead of the height of the fill area.



See also [sugar3.graphics.progressicon](https://developer.sugarlabs.org/sugar3/sugar3.graphics.progressicon.html).

results.description:
Currently toolkit produces a `.xo` file even when some fields which are standard (but not enforced) like License, summary, categories (inside `activity.info`  and even `po` files folder are not present. This creates a situation when an activity doesn't even contain metadata like License and a small description. Enforcing it inside the toolkit would allow a common pattern and standardize the activity ecosystem.

Also there is no easy way to install sugar-toolkit, one need to manually copy the necessary files to python distribution folder,  a pip package would really help in easing the process  of setting up a development environment.

These points were raise during a the weekly GSOC meeting, [conversation here](http://meeting.sugarlabs.org/sugar-meeting/2017-07-17#i_2898560)

results.description:
From http://lists.sugarlabs.org/archive/sugar-devel/2016-May/052710.html and replies, it seems some dependencies must be changed based on XO model and on 32 or 64 bit architechture. 

During GCI, Walter set up a platform variable that activities can test to determine the environment. This will become increasingly important to developers, so should be stressed (and perhaps part of Hello World.)

The XO-1.75 needs ARMv7 binaries, while older XOs used x86. Activity bundles should include .so files for each supported architecture. There is not yet a formal bundle structure for handling multi-arch, as it was designed for platform-independent code like Python, but since a bundle can have arbitrary library folders, an activity using compiled libraries must implement code to selecting the right one for the current architecture.

After a few activities have done this, perhaps a convention can be recommended in these docs for others to follow.

(Thanks to Tony Anderson and Bert Freudenberg for clarifying this issue)
results.name: sugar-docs Issue: #87: Stress the importance of testing the platform variable

results.description:
We have many ways to generate SVG in Sugar, notably with Turtle Blocks and Music Blocks. STL is a common format used in 3-D printing (most 3-D printer software will convert STL to GCODE, the native language of the printer). It would be nice to be able to export STL from either the Python or JavaScript version of Turtle Blocks, essentially extruding the SVG into a 3-D object.

By way of example, you can go online to https://www.tinkercad.com/ (or other proprietary sites) to convert SVG to STL.

results.description:
Issue: As mentioned in the bug [1].

It is difficult to connect a Sugar device to multiple school servers because

the user is required to perform few manual steps to clear a previous

registration. Also, new registration is performed even  when a laptop

tries to connect to an school server, where it has already registered

previously. This caused the original backup-url and back-up path to

change on the server causing inefficiency.

Solution: The solution involves a few automated checks and tasks that

are performed to overwrite new registration details, store previous

registration details and restore the details when an old server is connected.

UI: Just the 'Register' and 'Register again' button are replaced with

a single 'Connect to server' button on the FavouriteView desktop. It was

done to provide a non confusing simple and constant button to the user, as

his/her final motive is to get Sugar settings configured with the server

regardless of the fact that it is registering, registering again or

simply restoring settings of previous registration. Also it will mark

the change in the background functionality.

Server: I tried it on XSCE School Server release-6.0 on a CentOS7 machine.

No server side modification was done to achieve it apart from enabling

'Services for XO Laptops such as Registration, Backup, and Activity Server'

in 'Configure' section of schoolserv...
results.name: sugar Issue: #679: Connect to multiple School Server easily

results.description:
Task: Review and update this patch based on the Collaboration Wrapper.

File transfer channels are a powerful solution for transfering data

1-to-1 over telepathy.  However, currently the shell will try to

claim all file transfer channels and show a notification to the

user.

This commit makes the shell ignore the channel if it has the

content type of 'x-sugar/from-activity'.  It will instead pass it

to the telepathy client specified in the file name.  The file name

was used to house the client name because there does not appear

to be a dedicated place for this information in telepathy.

Activities can still use the description to store their metadata.

**Note**:  This patch makes a lot more sense with the new collab wrapper patch.  There is lots of lines changed in the collab wrapper to use file transfers.  I need to review those myself before I can share that.  I will update this pull request when that happens.
results.name: sugar Issue: #621: Allow activities to pass file transfers without shell notification

A trill is a (rapid) alternation between two different notes or two different chords. (Maybe more than two is theoretically possible, but I have never seen it in music, I think)

Fill: 1/2 note time
Rate: 1/16th notes
Note(s): C4 <-> D4

If it is agreed that this would be useful as a block, we can make a mockup.
results.name: MusicBlocks Issue #438: Trill block

results.description:
_Tremolo_ is a single repeated note or a single repeated chord; 

http://lilypond.org/doc/v2.19/Documentation/notation/short-repeats#tremolo-repeats


Currently the user can achieve tremolo via repeats and adjusting note value, but this is counter to the way people usually think of tremolo. Typically, one starts with the amount of space that they would like to fill, and then how rapid they would like the tremolo to be.



Example:

Fill: 1/2 note time

What if, instead of a dropdown, we had a (javascript?) menu for choosing pitch. It would be similar to a clock.

 

This selector on the Gnome Outreachy site is somewhat relevant:

[screenshot from 2017-02-14 12 49 32](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13454579/22941581/0e808b56-f2b4-11e6-9e2b-e40c8b42fc98.png)

_Try it at [Outreachy](https://outreachy.gnome.org/?q=program_home&prg=8). I think the code may be at https://outreachy.gnome.org/skins/easterngreen/js/processing.js_



For our default pitch system (12 tones and C major as default mode) there would be 7 pitches in the center part of the circle. Hovering over any of those would reveal other options (with "natural" being the default) that would augment the circle outward slightly (as in the outreachy code). I suppose that choosing other keys might put the notes relevant to that key (when the "set mode" block has been clicked for that mode, for example) as the central 7.



The exact implementation is not so important, but it would be nice to show pitch as cyclic. This, in conjunction with **relative octave enhancement https://github.com/walterbender/musicblocks/issues/601** would make the nature of pitch and octave more accessible, I think.

results.description:
Say you have a sequence of blocks:



play note A

step pitch 1

step pitch 1

play note D



You should get A, B, C, D



But if you play this set of blocks backward, you would get:

D, E, F, A



Maybe we want step pitch to flip its polarity inside of a backward block?

D, C, B, A



Of course, there is the additional issue of using step pitch without having set a starting pitch, which is why I explicitly set D in the example.
results.name: MusicBlocks Issue: #699: ambiguous interaction between backwards block and step pitch

results.description:
At some point, we should start adding embellishments.



There are many, many ornaments. Some are documented here:



https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Musical_ornaments



BASICS: (Off the top of my head)

Upper/lower neighbor -- this can be chromatic (not key dependant) or diatonic (key dependant); note that ornaments like mordents are combinations of upper/lower neighbors (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mordent)

Trill and Tremolo -- https://github.com/walterbender/musicblocks/issues/438

Slide -- there are various ways to slide from one pitch to another.

Grace note -- a quick movement from one note to another; there are a couple different possible performances of grace note.

Fermata -- Also known as a "grand pause", holding a particular note or notes for dramatic effect. Also see https://github.com/walterbender/musicblocks/issues/521



There are more, this is just a start.

It may be worth assigning a new palette for these kinds of functions.



More info:

http://lilypond.org/doc/v2.18/Documentation/music-glossary/ornament
results.name: MusicBlocks Issue: #713: Embellishments/Ornaments

results.description: We mostly use a clamp to specify volume or a relative change in volume, but this can be limiting. For example, if you want to articulate the first beat of each measure, using the on-beat-do mechanism, you cannot change the volume by using a clamp. The problem is that when specifying relative volume changes, you also need to know when to revert the effect, which is a clamp is well suited for. We need to revisit our current set of options and come up with a consistent and robust set of blocks for managing programmatic change to volume.

results.description:

http://lilypond.org/doc/v2.18/Documentation/notation/long-repeats

example:

\repeat volta repeatcount musicexpr



There is also a way to do first and second endings:

\repeat volta repeatcount musicexpr

\alternative {

  { musicexpr }

}



For smaller items, and in places where it makes sense, we should consider short-repeats



http://lilypond.org/doc/v2.18/Documentation/notation/short-repeats



example:

repeat percent number musicexpr



I assign myself to investigate this further and come up with some rules for how MB might parse the input to make desired output.

results.description:
This piggy backs off of the idea for changes to "set key" described https://github.com/walterbender/musicblocks/issues/832



In the same way that the mathematical solution for a combination of math blocks is shown in the upper-right hand corner of the math blocks, I think that the scale degree number for a pitch can be shown in the upper right hand corner of a pitch block.



What note constitutes as tonic (equal to scale degree 1) would be dependant on the key/mode set by a "set key" block. If none are present, the program assumes c major.



The implications of the proposal for changes in "set key" behavior described https://github.com/walterbender/musicblocks/issues/832 are that since Do is not always 1, Re is not always 2, etc. the solfege and the scale degree are not always the same (unless the transpose block has also been invoked, of course). (If this is unclear or confusing, please ask questions.)



If the user is using "scale degree" blocks the pitch name would be displayed instead (since the scale degree is already obvious). It could be be displayed in either alphabet (a,b,c, etc) or solfege, but the latter would be more consistent with our current approach.

results.description:
Further to the discussion at https://github.com/walterbender/musicblocks/issues/854, it would be nice to see functionality for allowing the export of a MB program as a wav / ogg / mp3 file.



One implementation possibility:

Connect the Tone.Master node (where all the MB audio is sent) to a MediaStreamAudioDestination node (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AudioContext/createMediaStreamDestination, https://github.com/Tonejs/Tone.js/wiki/Connections) and then save the resulting MediaStream as a file / make it available through an `<audio>` element. The 'recording' of audio into the MediaStream could be done through the user playing the piece in the 'playback' mode that has recently been developed for MB. The only issue would be that the user would need to wait for the code to play back (in normal time) to export it as a file - one could try to get around this problem, but it would mean major changes to MB's synth engine.
results.name: MusicBlocks Issue: #866: Export as .wav

However:

* I do not think we should have a separate block with movable solfege specific syllables (see chart below)

* I do not think we should change the design of our current block that has Do Re Mi Fa Sol La Ti only. Its simplicity is good.

I think it makes sense to show the solfege specific syllables during MB's various forms of slow playback (e.g. step-by-step) the same way that it shows math calculations during slow playback. results.description:
Story forks `gst-launch`, an unversioned binary wrapper for whatever version of GStreamer is installed on a system.  Yet the remainder of Story explicitly uses GStreamer 1.0 via Python GI API.



Only performance impact is having two versions of GStreamer in memory, and it should be rare.



It does make downstream packaging dependencies complicated though.



So we might either;



* change to using `gst-launch-1.0` because we know it will be there; or,

* change from using `gst-launch` to an inline player (as used by Portfolio or the similar audio recorder in Music Keyboard).
results.name: story Issue: #10: Unversioned gst-launch

Rather than a series of `wget` and `unzip` commands, this might be simplified to a list of URLs and code that parses the list;

```bash

for URL in $(<files/Sugar-activities-list); do

    BASE=$(basename $URL)

    FILE=files/Sugar-activities/$BASE

    if [ ! -e $FILE ]; then

        wget $URL -P files/Sugar-activities

    fi

    unzip $FILE -d ${BUILDDIR}/chroot/usr/share/sugar/activities

done

```

results.description:
So, this has no tests of any kind at all right now :cry:  As seen in #147, we can eaisly break things because there are lots of different browsers and lots of code that is fragile.  I know that @walterbender, you say this codebase needs refactoring, so why not get talking more specifically about it?

Our current architecture merges the "model" and "view" in our code, which makes testing harder.  It does not make it impossible to write tests though, it just means that we are more BDD tests than TDD tests.  Separating the model and view means it is much easier to test the model (it is pure js!) but does not fix the issue with the view being canvas (harder to test than DOM).

So, how do we test with js and canvas?  I think this is 2 parts, how do we unit test and how do we test canvas?

For unit testing there are many options.  I have used [QUnit](http://qunitjs.com/) previously.  It is based inside your browser and is very simple, agile and nice :smile:.  Because it is browser based, it is super easy (load web page in browser) to test everywhere!  You can test in many environments and even production eaisly.  Another framework (no experience with this one sorry) is [Jasmine](https://github.com/jasmine/jasmine).  It is not based within the DOM, so must be run using a node and node-canvas.  The advantage is that we have examples to draw off, as it used by easel js.

For testing ...

results.description:
@llaske I am curious, why did you choose the Apache 2.0 license for Sugarizer? 

I am worried that many python Sugar programs are licensed under GPLv2. 

When you port a program from one language to another, the port is a derivative of the original under copyright (like translating a novel from French to English.) Therefore GPLv2 programs ported from Python to JavaScript must also be licensed under the GPLv2. 

It seems that much of python Sugar is licensed under GPLv2. It also seems to me that any program written for the python Sugar desktop must be considered a combined work with the desktop, and thus required to be licensed under terms compatible with the GPLv2.

GPLv2 is not compatible with the Apache 2.0 license (but GPLv3 is.) 

Therefore if you are keen to use Apache 2.0 instead of GPL, I guess we'll need to work with the community to re-license Sugar under GPLv3.

----

Some other projects, e.g., Turtle Blocks, are licensed under AGPLv3. Is that compatible with Apache 2.0?

results.description:
I'm creating my first web activity and I've used the ActivityTemplate

from Sugarizer repository.



However I'm failing to get my activity to run under Sugar.



The same happens when I try to run any of the Sugar-web activities

contained in `activities/` directory of Sugarizer repository.



However when I download Markdown.activity from ASLO, I am able to run it.



The failure consists of the activity icon not becoming colored and no

datastore object being created. Furthermore, there are no errors in the

Sugar logs that I can find.



I'm testing with Sugar 0.110 as packaged in Debian Testing.



Indeed there is an error in the Inspector Javascript Console:



[Error] Invalid url for WebSocket ws://127.0.0.1:undefined

    (anonymous function) (sugaros.js:19)

    (anonymous function) (env.js:29)



[Error] SyntaxError (DOM Exception 12): The string did not match the expected pattern.

    (anonymous function) (sugaros.js:19)

    (anonymous function) (sugaros.js:19)

    (anonymous function) (env.js:29)



This can be reproduced by copying any activity (above is from Stopwatch.activity) into ~/Activities in a Sugar Desktop.

When I switch the lib/sugar-web directory for the official sugarlabs/sugar-web, then it works fine in Sugar 0.110, but then, it doesn't work in Sugarizer anymore.
